messages: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:40): Mr Last Week (whom I assume is reading this): Why the song for me in the latest post?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:44): hmm, http://www.w3.org/2009/09/11-hcg-minutes.html really is fairly interesting (MO link)
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (18:47): I need your password
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:09): Any help for a html4 dog to learn html5?
f9e12e0466f4d059b78bb3f863633092 (19:09): d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c - start here http://www.whatwg.org/
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:10): diveintohtml5.org is purty.
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:11): Just wondering, can the new tags, like canvas, be used with Php
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:12): They can be used with PHP to the same extent that any other HTML element can be used with PHP
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:13): I mean, can the canvas content be passed as a GET/POST?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:16): Do you mean something like uploading the bitmap content of a canvas to a server?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:16): If so, you can use canvas.toDataURL() to get a string representing the canvas bitmap (encoded as a PNG), and then upload that
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:35): Also, Local Storage?
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:40): Sounds scary
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (19:46): If a browser doesn't support a certain feature, are there libraries to emulate the feature?'
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:47): There are for some features
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (19:47): there is for the non-embedded stuff
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:47): e.g. there's libraries to emulate <canvas> in IE
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (19:48): are they any good?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:52): No, unless you only want to do pretty simple things

7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (20:13): d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c, plugins are more complicated, though. you can have theora and vorbis by adding a qucktime thingy, but the user has to explicitly install it.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (20:13): also, i think there was a web forms 2.0 javascript library
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:20): How would you mark up blog comments? I've chosen an article containing an ordered list of articles.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (20:22): Steve^, following the spec example ?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:22): whereabouts is that?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:23): Steve^: In http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:23): ducks
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:23): yes, that's the spec, well done
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:23): I actually have a PDF version open, so shoo!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:23): ewww, print media ;P
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (20:26): Steve^: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/sections.html#the-article-element
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (20:26): specifically, "where article elements are nested..."
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:27): oops, thank you
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:27): I read it, but not hard enough

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:30): javascript:'<frameset cols=*,*><frame src=http://validator.nu/?doc='+encodeURIComponent(location.href)+'><frame src=http:/ a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554.html5.org/outliner/process.py?url='+encodeURIComponent(location.href)+'></frameset>'
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:30): bookmarklet to validate and check outline
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:35): awesome
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:37): wonders if he'll have time to rewrite the outliner this month
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:38): what's wrong with it?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:38): It could be 100% more awesome.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:38): It's software, therefore it needs to be rewritten
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:43): annevk2: Is there any reason that scrollIntoView isn't in CSSOM View?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (20:43): Steve^: using an ordered list is semantic abuse; document order is ordering enough for this case
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): where do you draw the line on that?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): comments are something that I would actually number
d30973809f2e4238b7eb2bac9241674c (21:01): Is there still a way to use frames?

fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (21:03): Steve^: <ol> means that if you change the order of the <li>s, you've changed the meaning of the text. document order provides enough semantic ordering, <ol> too much.
